snippet: With a trillion-dollar cache of oil, gold and other resources underground, hopes of self-sufficiency in Afghanistan are tempered by worries about corruption and security.
abstract: Afghan officials and mining industry experts say the potential mineral resource boom in the country seems increasingly imperiled by corruption, violence and intrigue, and has put the government's vulnerabilities on display; discovery of Afghanistan's trillion-dollar reservoir of natural resources once brought hope of a path toward becoming a more self-sufficient country.

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Kabul, Afghanistan; Habib Zahori from Bamian Province, Afghanistan; and an employee of The New York Times from Khost Province, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: With a trillion-dollar cache of oil, gold and other resources underground, hopes of self-sufficiency in Afghanistan are tempered by worries about corruption and security.

headline.seo: Afghans Wary as Efforts Pick Up to Tap Mineral Riches
headline.main: Potential for a Mining Boom Splits Factions in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: Potential Boom In Afgan Mining Stokes Rivalries
